commit.message:
Update CHANGELOG and bump version to 2.1.0

Update tilt.gemspec so it doesn't need to be regenerated
via a rake task.

Fixes #301, #380, #385, #393, #384, #390
Add Ruby 3.2 to CI

Various README fixes

Don't mention Tilt 1.4.  Tilt 2.0 came out over 9 years ago.

Remove mentions of deprecated Less, BlueCloth, and Sigil templates.

Remove mention of fastercsv, since we dropped Ruby 1.8 support.

Make it clear that we will not accept new community maintained
template engines.

Add Erubi as supporting template compilation.

Only add coffee-script in Gemfile in CI

coffee-script is soft-deprecated (no deprecation message, but
considered deprecated by the maintainers). Not sure we should
deprecate tilt's support, but this makes it so `bundle install`
will not attempt to install something considered deprecated.

Fixes #384

Use UnboundMethod#bind_call on Ruby 2.7+

bind_call is faster than bind.call, because it doesn't allocate a
Method object.

Add Tilt::Template#freeze_string_literals?

If this returns true, frozen-string-literal: true is set when
compiling the template method.  It is false by default, and
will need to be manually set to true in the template classes
that could support it.

Support :freeze option for ERB, Erubis, and Erubi template to
use frozen string literals.

Avoid printing deprecation warnings when running Erubis tests.
Similar change already made when running the ERB tests.
Prefer Haml::Template from Haml 6
Clean up Travis CI

Use attr_reader for a couple methods

attr_reader methods are faster than normal methods.

Deprecate BlueCloth, Less, and Sigil support

None of these are tested in CI.

BlueCloth conflicts with RDiscount.  It could theoretically be
tested in CI if RDiscount was in primary templates and BlueCloth
in secondary templates, but considering BlueCloth hasn't had a
release in over 10 years, and Tilt supports many other markdown
formats, there isn't a good reason to keep supporting it.

Less on CRuby depends on therubyracer, which no longer works on
modern Ruby due to changes in Psych.  I tried enabling it in CI,
and it won't install (https://github.com/jeremyevans/tilt/runs/7812514562?check_suite_focus=true#step:4:155).
Less hasn't had a release in over 8 years, and therubyracer hasn't
had a release in over 5 years.

Sigil doesn't have a gem, and isn't even packaged for my operating
system (OpenBSD).  It's possible we could test it in CI if it is
packaged for whatever Linux distro CI uses, but I doubt the usage
of tilt/sigil is high enough to justify that.

If any tilt user really needs these template engines, they can just
copy the related template file and require it manually.

Support coverable templates

Ruby's coverage library does not support code loaded eval (and
similar methods like {class,module,instance}_{eval,exec}). However,
it would be nice to be able to get code coverage for your web
application views. One simple way to do this is to write a file
with the compiled template code, and then load it

This adds Tilt::Template#compiled_path=, for setting a path
for the template.  There may be multiple compiled files based
on this path if the template is render with multiple scope classes
and/or local variables.

load is used instead of require to prevent breaking things when
the same path would be reused.  The methods are unbound after
the file is loaded, so using load instead of require makes sense
for that.  We do not want to delete the file after loading, since
the main reason to use this feature is for coverage testing.

Trying this in a real application showed indentation warnings in
verbose warning mode.  Fix those by not indenting the compiled
template method preamble.

In my testing, the coverage library didn't pickup relative loads
by default, so this uses File.expand_path to expand the paths
passed on Tilt::Template#compiled_path=.  That's not required,
but it seems useful enough to make it the default behavior.
Add matrix gem to Gemfile on Ruby 3.1+, so prawn tests run

Remove less/therubyracer from Gemfile

therubyracer will not install in CI, and since it won't install,
there is no point installing less.

Since we cannot test less in CI, I recommend deprecating less in
2.1 and removing in 2.2.

Fix Gemfile to get more template engines tested in CI

The erubi template was not tested in CI as it wasn't in the Gemfile.
Add erubi to Gemfile in the primary group, since it has priority for
.erb files, and move erubis to the secondary group.

The less gem was installed in the primary group, but the tests
wouldn't run as therubyracer gem wasn't installed.  Move less to
the secondary group, and install therubyracer.

Remove the restriction on the pdf-reader gem, since tests pass with
the current version of pdf-reader. That should hopefully allow the
prawn tests to run in CI (they previously didn't).

After this, the only tests not run in CI are BlueCloth and Sigil.
We may want to deprecate those in 2.1 and remove in 2.2.

Fix broken rst-pandoc template

This template wasn't tested in CI, and has been broken since
a168cc9e7ae86c6e9769c4692ee7153b885906ef changed the require.

With the require fixed, their was one test failure, where it
appears the :escape_html works now, so I updated the test.
Make pandoc tests pass when default encoding is not UTF-8

Add Mapping#unregister(*extensions)

This makes it simpler to remove already registered extensions.

Fixes #330

Switch to minitest/spec

Instead of building a poor clone of minitest/spec inside test_helper,
just use minitest/spec since it is already loaded (by minitest/autorun).

This eliminates top-level constants being defined by tilt_template_test.rb.
The helper classes used in the file are now anonymous classes assigned to
local variables.

In addition to switch to mintest/spec, the following fixes are made:

1. Avoid displaying warning when testing deprecated
   Tilt::ERBTemplate.default_output_variable in the Erubis tests
   (similar change made previously in the ERB tests).

2. The pandoc tests in tilt_markdown_test.rb are not run if
   nokogiri is not installed (the tests depend on nokogiri).

3. Avoid loading tilt/sigil if sigil is not installed.

4. Paths adjusted in the markaby tests in order to get them
   passing in my environment.

In my environment, there are test failures if both bluecoth and
rdiscount are installed, since they both define the same
non-static function (markdown_version). If either is installed,
but not both, the related tests pass (this was true both before
and after the change to minitest/spec).

The diff is best viewed with --color-words -b.

Add Mapping#register_pipeline for handling template pipelines

This makes it easy to combine multiple template engines into
a single processing pipeline, by taking the output of one
template and using it as the input to another template,
returning the final output as the result of the pipeline.

Remove more Ruby < 2 compatibility code

Split TiltTemplateTest into two classes. There is setup/teardown
blocks in the middle of the file that you might expect are only
for the following tests, but they actually apply to all tests
in the file, including the tests above the setup/teardown blocks
that aren't using what the setup/teardown blocks provide.

This is best viewed ignoring whitespace differences.

Add with_default_encoding and with_utf8_default_encoding helper methods

Use these to temporarily change the default external encoding for
individual tests, instead of setup/teardown blocks at the suite level.

Use these to fix issues in the babel template tests when the default
external encoding is not UTF-8.
Remove adding test to load path in rake test task

Avoid printing warning when running erb template tests

This tests the deprecated Tilt::ERBTemplate.default_output_variable
feature, which we do want to raise a warning so users know to change.
However, there is no point printing the error when running Tilt's
tests.

Avoid "Invalid ERB trim mode:" warning

Passing :trim=>false as the tests do should not result in a warning.

Fix incorrect test

The "encoding with magic comment" test was supposed to check
that Tilt will respect the magic comment of the template source.
However, Tilt doesn't do that. Tilt will extract the magic comment
of generated ruby code for precompiled templates.  However, the
template source code must be valid in the default external encoding
if you do not provide a :default_encoding option.

The test worked correctly when the default external encoding was
compatible with the magic comment, but it didn't even
check that the encoding of the resulting render matched.  Modify
the test to check that it will use the source encoding if given.

Also modify the following test to ensure it actually tests that
render result has the correct encoding.

Fix errors when default external encoding is not UTF-8

This fixes 6 test errors/failures when the default external encoding
was set to US-ASCII instead of UTF-8.

Chomp newline in sass tests

In my environment these fail due to render returning a string ending
with a newline.  Since the newline doesn't cause any problems in
CSS, I don't think we should force remove it in the template engine.
It seems acceptable to allow output both with and without a newline.

Avoid loading minitest plugins by default

Minitest will attempt to go through all installed gems looking
for plugins, and will attempt to enable those plugins automatically,
even in cases where use of the plugin is not desired.  Turn off
this misfeature.

Switch to require_relative

Use require_relative to load tilt in test_helper, avoiding the
need to require it in almost all template files.

This allows you to run individual files via ruby:

  ruby test/tilt_template_test.rb

This makes it no longer necessary to add the test directory to the
load path, except for one test for autoload, so do that locally
in that test.

Add a missed require for pathname to tilt_template_test to ensure
that can be run in an isolated fashion.

Remove unnecessary thread requires, as thread is available by
default in Ruby 1.9+.

Remove unnecessary encoding magic comments, since source code
encoding defaults to UTF-8 in Ruby 2.0+.

Remove use of Bundler.setup

If use of bundler is desired, bundle exec should be used.  This
is already done in CI.

With the current setup, I cannot even run rake -T to see available
tasks without installing gems.  When running tests for one engine,
I should not need to install tests for other engines I'm not using.

All template engine tests already have checks for whether the
engine is installed, and if the engine is not available, it prints
a useful message and skips the tests for that engine.
